sentence: Procter & Gamble (PG) released their results this morning, an event that I always look forward to.
Not for the results themselves; as one would expect from a mega multinational with blanket analyst coverage, earnings are usually a little boring and predictable.
What I look forward to is the quarterly appearance of P&G’s CFO, Jon Moeller on CNBC’s Squawkbox.
Moeller gives an assessment of the company’s quarter that is usually remarkably candid for an executive, but it is his take on the broader global economic conditions that I find illuminating.
Understandably, as CFO of the world’s largest manufacturer and supplier of branded consumer products, Moeller has a unique feel for global conditions.
What he, and the company in general, also has is vast experience in dealing with those conditions as they change.
It was interesting, then, to hear him speak without bleating about strength in the U.S. dollar.
We have become accustomed already this quarter to CEOs laying the blame for disappointing numbers firmly at the feet of the currency.
I have pointed out in the past that, while that is a fair excuse to a certain extent, it often doesn’t quite add up.
Missing expectations by 20-25 percent can’t be completely explained by a 7 or 8 percent strengthening of the dollar.

Moeller, on the other hand, acknowledged that currency factors had influenced the results, but less than many would expect for a company that derives such a large proportion of its revenue from overseas.
Rather than just complain he highlighted what they have done to offset the effects.
There are an awful lot of corporate executives who could learn from that.
Currency fluctuations are a fact of life; dealing with them is the responsibility of a board and particularly of a CFO.
P&G’s strategy sounded like a decent blueprint that others could follow.
Yes, some hedging was involved, but they looked first to minimize the effects in other ways.
First and foremost they looked to increase local sourcing.
The last few years have seen huge increases in productivity, driven in part by aggressive outsourcing.
We tend to think of that only as a huge problem for developed nations, but another side effect has been to increase the effects of currency fluctuations.
Wherever a product is manufactured, if the raw materials are imported, changes in foreign exchange rates have an effect on margins.
P&G’s strategy of increased reliance on locally sourced products reduces that effect.
Moeller also pointed out that the most basic strategy of all for dealing with difficult times, cutting costs and improving efficiency can also be used to reduce the impact of a strong home currency.
These things don’t deal with the basic problem of translating profit made overseas back into dollars when that profit in local currency is devalued; that is where some hedging comes in.
What they do show, though, is that there are ways to mitigate the effects to a certain extent.
It is hard for somebody like me who has a dealing room background to get excited about a stock like PG.
Massive mature multinational corporations offer little in the way of growth potential or excitement.
As the 5 year chart above demonstrates, though, what they do offer is a great store of value over time.

That simple fact, combined with the knowledge that experience affords when things aren’t perfect, convinces me that as PG approaches the $80 level in reaction to missing on earnings it is a stock that investors should be looking to buy.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
